THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

NOVEMBER 7, 1902.

No 2

VACATION NOTES: ENGLAND.
ONDON loomed up in tourist geography during the past summer much as
Paris in an Exposition year—a place to be visited or avoided according to
. one's temper and purse. Recollection of the Queen's Jubilee crush had not
entirely faded, and when a resourceful Bloomsbury landlady wired, "sorry, but
no room," there was a cheerful reversal of plans, a season of recovery in Liverpool, and ultimate refuge in Ambleside, in the Lake Country.

t

If the placid beauty of the English Lake District fails to key one quite up
to guide-book phrase, certainly it has a gentle charm and a restful loveliness
that wins and holds. Literary association and natural environment are in a
rare unison that brings quiet and peace. One lazes and dreams, and the world
and all its unrest seem away forever.
. I doubt if any but Anglo-Saxon stuff could have reacted so well from the
disappointment and loss of the King's illness, and the abandoned coronation
ceremonies. Nothing had been spared to present a great spectacular display.
Even the staid old lady of Threadneedle Street had put her hand deep in the
corporate purse and expended several thousand pounds in arranging for illumination. When the bolt struck there was a moment of daze, and then John Bull
Pulled himself resolutely together. Householders took in their bunting; procession-stand owners refunded their receipts; hotels and restaurants returned to
normal tariffs, and The Times discontinued its leaders on the harmony of divine
kingship ceremonies with the ideals of parliamentary government. There was
damage, of course—and sometimes worse—but it was faced bravely and accepted
definitely.
It would be difficult to find better illustrations of the essential qualities of
the English character than those growing out of the three great events of the
mid-July weeks—the postponement of the King's coronation, the resignation of
Lord Salisbury, and the conclusion of the Boer War and Lord Kitchener's
return to London. Even to the transient sojourner, intent on other things, they
told of a people whose very bone and marrow are indomitable will and sturdy
resourcefulness.
But let the political caldron seethe and bubble as it might, the scholarship
of the world, all summer long, paid its uninterrupted tribute to England in the
British Museum and in the Public Record Office. To be able to secure at call
every book that you need is comfort; but to command it in a sense almost proprietary, to be made to feel—not merely to know—that the abundant resources
of great institutions exist for your aid and convenience—this is the luxury of

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

study, suggesting the dictum of our own dear sage that the happiness of life
consists in being paid for doing what you want to do.
J. H. H., '91.

IMPRESSIONS OF THE PRINCETON INAUGURATION.

t

HE proverb tells us that "familiarity breeds contempt," and sometimes it
is true. For extemple, I am afraid there is a tendency among many of
the humble members of our great institution to imagine sometimes that
the western limit of the work of the Johns Hopkins hardly reaches Eutaw
Street, rather than the Golden Gate. But that Hopkins man who has lived
through the year 1902 and is still within the bonds of such ignorance must be
a sluggard indeed. For the most renowned and brilliant scholars and educators
of our America would not have so clearly and unanimously, so enthusiastically
borne witness to the great power for enlightenment and truth which, starting
from this place, has gone forth to transform the whole life of the country, unless
they had meant what they said. To every Hopkins man, no matter how humble, February 22, 1902, was a memorable day.
But, as recently I watched the ceremonies attending the inauguration of
another president over another institution, it seemed to me that there too I
had a vision of a greater Hopkins than I had ever seen before. It is not merely
that President Wilson chose this University as the place among all others
which would best fit him for his great work,—it is the fact that he is a Hopkins man, not in mere outward semblace, but in the spirit. Yet this must not
be taken to mean that he is not also, and in a very deep sense, a Princeton man.
President Wilson knows and loves almost above everything else the Princeton
which has been handed down to him—a heritage which no wealth could have
bought, which no scholarship could have won, except after the life-long
devotion of many men strong in wisdom and in the knowledge of the Lord.
We may be sure that not a stone of this glorious building is to be cast down.
Yet, in his inauguration address, President Wilson distinctly says that he is
going to build something new upon this strong foundation. "We mean," he
says,"
to build a notable graduate college." And when we
hear him proceed to outline this plan, we see that it bears a striking resemblance to something that we have seen before, and have learned to admire with
all due humility. Not that it is a copy of anything else under the sun. President Wilson has very different materials to work with from those of any other
man, and he has a different, an original mind to mould them. But may we
not claim that the source of this new impulse which is to become operative in
one of the most conservative institutions in the country, is to be found in that
great idea which was first put into operation in Baltimore? To claim anything
less, would be to affirm that President Wilson, so closely connected with Johns
Hopkins, has been less affected by it than many thousands of comparative
strangers. Of course, this is to be taken for what it is worth, as the feeling of
one who knows very little of that for which this great University has stood,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

but it may still be an encouragement for study and for life of more value than
the exhortations of the greatest orator that ever lived. As we see the influence
of the Johns Hopkins spreading out into every field of activity—indeed, building upon the firm and tried foundation of a great college with far greater success than upon the more plastic but less secure ground of intellectual chaos to
be found in some less conservative institutions—even the humblest of us must
feel some little desire not to be entirely unworthy of that great University
which we have the right not only to admire but also to love.
3.G. M.,'01,
Princeton, N. J.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE Junior Bible class meets Tuesdays at 12.55, and the Freshman class at
12.00. The time for the Senior class is not definitely arranged yet.

t

The Mission Study class met Sunday, Nov. 2, at 4, with an attendance
of 11, and more are enrolled. This class will meet on alternate Sundays at the
named hour. An interesting course on India is now on.
The Week of Prayer for young men will be observed from Nov. 9th to 14th
by daily services. Sunday, Nov. 9th, at 4 30, Rev. Edwin B. Niver will be the
Speaker, and members of the Glee Club will sing. All Hopkins men should
come out. Monday and Friday there will be prayer services from 1.00 to 1.20
See the posters.
The University of California has about 250 men enrolled in Bible Study
Classes on the same course as we use. Hopkins men should look into this matter. The graduate class are attending Dr. Foote's class on Thursday at 5.

T. J. Stubbs, who was a graduate student in Economics at the University
last year, is now an instructor at the University School, Washington, D. C.

is now practicing law at Spokane, Washington.
Albert Shaw, Ph. D. of the University '84, and editor of the Review of Reviews, was instrumental in bringing together Mr. John Mitchell and Mr. Pierpont Morgan, and was present at their conference, which led to the settlement
of the recent coal strike.
Toyokichi Iyenaga, Ph. D. of the University in 1890, will deliver on Monday next, at the Masonic Temple, a lecture on "Japan, Old and New." Dr.
Iyenaga has been for some years Professor of Political Economy at Semmo
Gakko, Tokyo, Japan.

$30,000 IN GIFTS TO THE UNIVERSITY.

e•

HE Board of Trustees of the University Monday afternoon accepted two
donations to the Hopkins. The gifts embrace $30,000 and came as a
surprise to the Board.
The offer of Dr Christian A. Herter, of New York, a graduate of the Hopkins, and his wife, to give $25,000 for the foundation of a memorial lectureship
in the medical department was received and accepted. The lectureship "is designed to promote a more intimate knowledge of the researches of foreign investigators in the realm of medical science." This end is to be secured by inviting each year some eminent worker in physiology or pathology to deliver one
or more lectures at the Johns Hopkins University upon a subject with which
he has been identified. The lecturer will receive as an honorarium the annual
income of the endowment.
.
The committee to select the lecturer will consist of Dr. Welch, Dr. Osler
and Dr. Abel, subsequent vacancies in this committee being filled by choice of
the remaining members in stich a way that pathology, physiological chemistry
and clinical medicine shall continue to be represented. There is no bar to opening the proposed lectureship to leaders in medical research in this country, if
this should ultimately appear desirable.
Mr. R. Brent Keyser sent a letter in which he referred to the matter of surveying and looking after the Homewood property, recently donated to the University, and offered to give $5000 to obtain the necessary expert assistance.
The gift was accepted and Mr. Keyser was voted the hearty thanks of the
Board.

0MORROW afternoon, at Westminster, Md., the football team plays its
first game of the season—if we except the eight-minute contest with Loyola
last Saturday. Western Maryland has put up a wonderfully strong game
this season, defeating our old rival, the University of Maryland, sixteen to
nothing. Our light players, with but three weeks of practice behind them, will
have their work cut out and ready for them when they line up at Westminster.
And in recognition of the sporting spirit in which they accept such an unequal
contest, they deserve the immediate and practical support of the entire undergraduate student body. Three years ago a green Hopkins team went up to
Westminster and defeated Western Maryland in a hard fought battle. In
speaking of the game afterwards several of the Hopkins men were heard
to say that it made all the difference in the world to them to hear the J. H. U.
songs and yells which were given with such spirit by the 60 rooters who accompanied the team. Much more will this be the case tomorrow, when our practically untried eleven meets a powerful team. Every man in the four undergraduate classes who can possibly take the time off should add his name to the list
on the bulletin-board of those who are to accompany the team. The train leaves
Union Station at 10.17 a. m., and it is expected that there will be a special car
for the team and rooters. Every man who turns up tomorrow with a flag and
a megaphone and, above all, a voice in good working order, is helping our team
to get the dash and spirit that they will need to win. All aboard!

e

THE NEWS-LETTER.

7

HERE is one method of assisting the Musical Clubs in their work,—a
method, too, which would produce practical and immediate results,—
which is little practiced at the University. This is, the suggestion to
the leaders of the various clubs of selections suitable for performance. "It is
Very
the leader's business to hunt up good pieces himself," someone says.
true; but it is also the leader's business to do a hundred other things with
which he cannot be helped by outsiders, and it will materially aid him in getting through his work to have ready at hand a large list of selections from
which to choose in making up a program. Of course, each leader attempts to
keep up with the music of the day, and is constantly on the watch for "something that will go," But it is impossible for any one man to keep track of the
mass of new songs, marches and waltzes that are produced every season. He
can attend all the comic operas,—and to some this may seem a not unpleasant
task,—be can keep his ears on the alert for a promising ditty whistled on the
street, and he can even, if he is a nervy man, write music himself. But he cannot fail to miss every season a certain number of new and old selections which
he would have been glad to consider, and possibly to adopt. The moral of all
this is, that every tuneful soul in the college has a chance to help the clubs by
sending in the names of pieces that he thinks will suit.
For the Glee Club, "close harmony" and melodies of a kind to bring out
the contrasts in the different voices are desired; for the Banjo Club, snappy
marches and dances which set the foot involuntarily marking time; for the
Mandolin Club, bright airs and dreamy waltzes. Some who read this may take
the hint, and put the leaders on the track of some good music.

Z

N another page appear some notes on Dr. Woodrow Wilson's inauguration
as President of Princeton University. President Wilson has been connected with many institutions of learning in this country—Princeton,
Wake Forest, Tulane, Vale, Bryn Mawr, Wesleyan, New York Law School.
From several of these he has received degrees. But we are proud to note, from
his own words and declared policy, that his work at the Johns Hopkins, leading
to his Ph.D. in 1886, has ever been an especial source of inspiration and benefit
to him. He is in the first rank of our distinguished graduates, and our pride in
him is mingled with congratulations on the early recognition of his worth.

O

GAIN comes the pleasant task of chronicling gifts to the University. The
donation from Dr. Christian A. Herter, of New York, and his wife, of
$25,000 for a memorial lectureship in the medical department, is characterized by the medical faculty as "a benefit, not only to the University, but to
the medical profession throughout the country." And Mr. R. Brent Keyser,in
presenting $5000 for the services of landscape architects in surveying the Homewood grounds, has given most timely aid to a step which brings us a little
nearer to our constant aim—the University at Homewood.

HERE are now three places open on THE NEWS-LETTER board of editors.
Two are for Freshmen,—one as assistant athletic editor, and one as
assistant news editor. The other place is that of assistant business
manager, and is open to members of 1904. The elections will be held week
after next, so that contestants should hand in as much work as possible before
that time.

O'C

FOR THE UNDERGRADUATE.
HE Senior Class elections resulted as follows: H. K. Tootle, President;
Philip R. Straus, Vice-President; G. Drayton Strayer, Secretary; E. P.
Sandrock, treasurer; J. A. Addison, Historian; T. W. Glocker, Poet.
Matthai, Pagon and Bird were appointed as a committee to report on a class
gift to the Trophy Room.

t

"Who stole the Chess Club Poster ?" This ornate creation was the pride
of the Chess Club organizing committee, and they are looking for the miscreant
who removed it from the bulletin board A liberal reward will be paid for its
return to Addison, '03, or Glocker, '03.
The Senate and House debates on Nov. 12th and 13th will have as subject:
"Resolved, That a voter is justified in concealing his party affiliations." Leader
Ammen of the Ministry will be defended by Tootle, Hildt and Pl.aggemeyer ;
while Leader Custis, of the opposition, will make use of Strayer, Pessagno and
Bamberger. In the House: Hawkins, Maynard and Stollenwerck, affirmative;
Porter, W. W. Kohn, L. G. Wallis, negative.
The subject of instructors keeping their classes overtime is the bone for
many biters just at present, and not without reason. Even for the most strenuous minds, ten minutes rest in an hour from intense mental strain is found
beneficial, and when this is cut down to five minutes, or three, it loses much of its
virtue. Moreover, for many students the between-bells time is the only chance
to transact the daily business consequent on college interests, and they are seriFinally, any instructor
ously handicapped at being ''cut short" on this time
whose ideas are so depraved that he really enjoys keeping his class for five minutes in strained and anxious postures, ready to grab their books and run—such
a one should, in the opinion of the Kickers' Club, be consigned to the warmest
part of the seventh circle.
Dr. Guy Carleton Lee is organizing a class to read Blackstone. It will be
open only to Seniors and Juniors, and while intended primarily for prospective
law students, a number of students in other courses will pursue it.
"The University certainly has treated me 'white,'" said the undergrad.
"How was that?" inquired someone.
"Why, I paid my full tuition last fall, but was sick for most of the last
half-year, so the authorities have decided that for this year I need pay only half
my fees, and I save $9g 00."

sometimes give most
The first smoker of the Hullabaloo Club was marked by great enthusiasm.
It had been feared by some that the hotly contested class election, which was
scheduled to open that evening, would mar the enjoyment of those present, but
judging by the spirited way in which the numerous songs were sung, and the
appreciation of the refreshments provided, these fears were unfounded. There
was at first some difficulty in getting the piano past the narrow banisters; but
this was overcome by the combined ingenuity and strength of a few leading
spirits, and music held its pleasant sway. Altogether, it was felt that the
smoker was to be the forerunner of many more such enjoyable occasions.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS

The present candidates for the various clubs are as follows :
GLEE CLUB: First tenors, Cowles, Carver, Humrichouse, Coffin, Ingraham; second tenors, Hall, Wright, Nelson, Geiger and Longnecker; first
basses, Ford, Bryan, R. Pagon, Bell, Larwell, Haughton, Custis, Eyster;
second basses, Gilman, Licking, W. Pagon, Plaggemeyer, Engel, Pausch,
Randall.
BANJO CLUB: Banjeaurines, Marshall, Snowden, Mason, Jackson, Lanier,
Sladen; banjos, Baetjer, Randall; guitars, Martin, Bryan, Converse, W.
Pagon, Hill; bass banjo, Nelson.
MANDOLIN CLUB: First mandolins, Bryan, Nelson, Snowden, R. Pagon,
Boynton, Dill, Bevan, Stollenwerck, England; second mandolin, Super; first
violins, Engle, Miller; second violins, Geiger, Hull; viola, Lanier; 'cello, Gilman; clarinets, Redburn and Coffin; oboe, Dochez; guitars, Converse, Marshall, Hill, Martin, W. Pagon; bass banjo, Jackson.
This list will, of course, be much cut down before any trips are taken away
from Baltimore. The Glee Club is especially weak in second tenors, and there
is an opening for one or more good voices in this department. The Banjo Club
has three new pieces in preparation, and more will follow. Two of the banjeaurine parts this year will be played on an instrument known as the "banjobanjeaurine," which differs from the banjo only in having a shorter neck, and
which has a much sweeter tone than the banjeaurine, the head of which is much
larger.
The first of the four practice concerts will be as follows:
Friday afternoon, November 21, at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Friday night, November 28, at St. Mary's Church, Roland Park.

FOOTBALL.
APTAIN BLANCK and the players who stick out the present football
season deserve all kinds of laurels, for they have certainly been "up
against it."
The game with Loyola College at Clifton Park last Saturday was the latest
discouraging incident. A number of new and promising men had been gotten
out for several days before the game, and prospects were much brighter. One
or two slight injuries on the last practice day made it necessary to keep several
of the best men out, but notwithstanding this, it looked as if we were scheduled
for victory over a team like Loyola. The results show that other troubles were
on hand. The teams lined up before a crowd which could not be held within
bounds, and any long run around the end had to be zig-zagged through spectators scattered all over the field. Loyola kicked off, and Hopkins brought the
ball back to the 45 yard line. Hitting the tackles proved effective and the ball
moved along until fumble No. 1 gave Loyola the ball. The collegians fussed
around the ends for several downs and then lost the ball. It was Hopkins
second chance to "get busy" and they did it in great style,—so great, in fact,
that when fumble No. 2 occurred, a Loyola man took the ball on the jump and
dodged in and out among the crowd until he- reached the goal line. In this
point the only park policeman became the most important factor in the game.
The ball had been in play just eight minutes, but it was 4 o'clock, and a permit giving the grounds to the Indians and the Never Sweats from four to six
came to view. And that was the finish. Hopkins left the field disgusted.
Such happenings are unusually discouraging under the present circumstances, but we are bound to stick it out, and there will be a turn in the tide
before the season ends.

ON THE CINDER PATH.
Nothing has been done in track work this year, but Captain R. C. Hoffman has the squad at work in the cage and some promising youngsters are
being developed. Several new men from the Medical School are among the
number, and the Freshman class has contributed several more, among them
Bond, Hull, Chism and Jackson.
Porter and several more from '04 are hard at work.
Tootle, Pessagno, Blanck, Nelson and Smith will be out from the Senior
class, and with several graduates a strong team should be developed.

The cancellation of our game with Gallaudet on the 15th is the result of a
decree from the Gallaudet faculty prohibiting their team to play any games this
season. Some of the students substituted Webster's Dictionary for the Chapel
Bible, and the suppression of the football team was the counter move of the

The news that the City College lacrosse team has started practice with a
large squad is very encouraging. When our neighbors begin to enter Hopkins,
they will greatly aid the 'Varsity in forming teams of experienced men.

Several of the baseball men got together in the trophy room last Friday
and talked over the prospects for the coming season. Several good players will
form the nucleus of a nine, and the chances are that Hopkins may be represented on the diamond when spring opens.

SHARSHALL GRASTY, '02, WEARS A HALO.
HE NEWS-LETTER prints below a very interesting clipping from the

C

Staunton News. THE NEWS-LETTER first thought of suppressing the
name of the subject of these encomiums and permitting its readers to
guess who the phenomenal scholar really was, the correct guesser to receive a
prize; but on reconsidering the matter it was felt that no correct guess could be
made, and the prize was therefore divided among the editors of THE NEWS
LETTER. It will be remembered that Mr. Grasty was half of the members of
"The Society for the Suppression of Vice." The following article is worthy of
perusal, as it teaches what great enchantment distance often lends.
"For any student to take the B. A. of Johns Hopkins in four years, while
pursuing a difficult scientific course, is a creditable achievement; but when it is
remembered that Sharshall Grasty entered Johns Hopkins late in the season of
1898.99, not fresh from his books like his classmates, but after two years of hard
work, the achievement may be considered admirable and extraordinary. There
are few finer young men physically, intellectually and morally than Sharshall
Grasty."
This last sentence is good enough to put on his tombstone.

WALTER'S WISDOM.
ALTER ran his hands reflectively through my hair. "Shampoo or hair
cut, sail?"
I'Shave," I answered sententiously. Walter proceeded to arrange
the instruments of torture. Like all barbers, he also proceeded to talk.
"Jes look at that face now, sah; you've been shaving yourself, sah. Ef Ah
had ybu all the time, sah, why you could take that face with you anywhere."
Walter is brutally frank. I protested that I had to take it with me anyway,
but the point was lost on him.
"You are too handsome a man, sah. not to have a clean, smooth face, sah.
You are, sah. Ef Ah had you all the time, sah, do you know what Ah would

TO

do?"
As he had filled my mouth with soap, reply was out of the question.
Walter continued his soliloquy as he stropped his razor.
"You ought to buy one of my tickets, sail, then you would always look
well. Why, there was a gem'mun in here yestiddy, sah, who said you was a
handsome man. Now ef Ah had you all the time Ah'd fix you so's you'd
always look well."
As a freshman that speech flattered my vanity, but I long ago found out
that he uses the same subtle flattery with everyone.
Just as Walter made one of his long sweeps across my classic jaw three
freshmen began to sing about its being always fair weather. Walter looked to
see who was disturbing the peace, and at the same time sliced me with neatness
and despatch. I remonstrated.

THE SOCIAL SETTLEMENT YOUTH.

NCE upon a time there was a youth who went to Levering Hall regularly.
There he was inoculated with a mad desire to lift his brother and to
fight the demon rum in his own den. One night as he was on his way to
a ping-pong party at the Social Settlement, he saw a burly man counting a roll
in front of a liquor shop.
"Stop!" he said to the man with the long green, "don't you know that is
not the place to spend your money?"

O

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The man only glared; then he snorted.
"Do not help to feed the demon rum."
He reached gently for the large individual with the comfortable wad to pull
him away from that haunt of vice and sin. The man thought that he was
making a pass at him; he ducked and countered with left to jaw. The youth
was "some punkins" in the gym, where you fight one minute and rest four, but
in this mix-up the spectators did not even offer Odds.
A few bystanders carried him to the nearest drug-store.
"Who was he?" he asked feebly when he came to.
"Dat!" admiringly exclaimed one of the brats whom the college youth had
come down to elevate, "dat bloke owns de bar. See?"
MORAL,: This fable teaches freshmen never to butt in before they are
introduced.

SILVER JUBILEE MEMORIAL VOLUME.

t

HE Johns Hopkins University Press has issued a beautiful bound volume
containing a complete account of the proceedings held last February on
the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the University.
The volume, which consists of almost 200 pages, contains the addresses of
President Remsen, President Emeritus Gilman, Governor Smith, as well as the
speeches of congratulation delivered by the different University presidents. A
full list of the delegates, representing nearly 100 universities and colleges, is
also given.
The address of Professor Woodrow Wilson, who has just been installed as
president of Princeton University, on his presenting the memorial volume to
Dr. Gilman, together with a copy of the congratulatory address, and Dr. Gilman's reply, are reprinted in full.
The Alumni banquet and the reunions and receptions held in connection
form chapters by themselves.
The work reflects great credit upon those having its publication in charge,
and will be an interesting souvenir to all who were present at the ceremonies,
as well as to the educational world in general. A copy has been presented to
all subscribers to the Alumni banquet.

A series of ten lectures on "The Weather and Climate of Baltimore and
Vicinity" will be given by Dr. Oliver l4. Fassig, on Thursdays at 11, in the
lecture room of the Geological Department. The lectures will extend through
November, December and January; the first will be given on Nov. 6.
The recently organized Geographical Society of Baltimore announces that
the first of its series of lectures for 1902-1903 will take place in McCoy Hall,
November 18, at 8 o'clock, when Dr. Angelo Heilprin will speak on "Martinique." The remaining five lectures will be given at the rate of one each
month until April.

VACATION NOTES: ENGLAND.
ONDON loomed up in tourist geography during the past summer much as
Paris in an Exposition year—a place to be visited or avoided according to
. one's temper and purse. Recollection of the Queen's Jubilee crush had not
entirely faded, and when a resourceful Bloomsbury landlady wired, "sorry, but
no room," there was a cheerful reversal of plans, a season of recovery in Liverpool, and ultimate refuge in Ambleside, in the Lake Country.

t

If the placid beauty of the English Lake District fails to key one quite up
to guide-book phrase, certainly it has a gentle charm and a restful loveliness
that wins and holds. Literary association and natural environment are in a
rare unison that brings quiet and peace. One lazes and dreams, and the world
and all its unrest seem away forever.
. I doubt if any but Anglo-Saxon stuff could have reacted so well from the
disappointment and loss of the King's illness, and the abandoned coronation
ceremonies. Nothing had been spared to present a great spectacular display.
Even the staid old lady of Threadneedle Street had put her hand deep in the
corporate purse and expended several thousand pounds in arranging for illumination. When the bolt struck there was a moment of daze, and then John Bull
Pulled himself resolutely together. Householders took in their bunting; procession-stand owners refunded their receipts; hotels and restaurants returned to
normal tariffs, and The Times discontinued its leaders on the harmony of divine
kingship ceremonies with the ideals of parliamentary government. There was
damage, of course—and sometimes worse—but it was faced bravely and accepted
definitely.
It would be difficult to find better illustrations of the essential qualities of
the English character than those growing out of the three great events of the
mid-July weeks—the postponement of the King's coronation, the resignation of
Lord Salisbury, and the conclusion of the Boer War and Lord Kitchener's
return to London. Even to the transient sojourner, intent on other things, they
told of a people whose very bone and marrow are indomitable will and sturdy
resourcefulness.
But let the political caldron seethe and bubble as it might, the scholarship
of the world, all summer long, paid its uninterrupted tribute to England in the
British Museum and in the Public Record Office. To be able to secure at call
every book that you need is comfort; but to command it in a sense almost proprietary, to be made to feel—not merely to know—that the abundant resources
of great institutions exist for your aid and convenience—this is the luxury of

2

study, suggesting the dictum of our own dear sage that the happiness of life
consists in being paid for doing what you want to do.
J. H. H., '91.

IMPRESSIONS OF THE PRINCETON INAUGURATION.

t

HE proverb tells us that "familiarity breeds contempt," and sometimes it
is true. For extemple, I am afraid there is a tendency among many of
the humble members of our great institution to imagine sometimes that
the western limit of the work of the Johns Hopkins hardly reaches Eutaw
Street, rather than the Golden Gate. But that Hopkins man who has lived
through the year 1902 and is still within the bonds of such ignorance must be
a sluggard indeed. For the most renowned and brilliant scholars and educators
of our America would not have so clearly and unanimously, so enthusiastically
borne witness to the great power for enlightenment and truth which, starting
from this place, has gone forth to transform the whole life of the country, unless
they had meant what they said. To every Hopkins man, no matter how humble, February 22, 1902, was a memorable day.
But, as recently I watched the ceremonies attending the inauguration of
another president over another institution, it seemed to me that there too I
had a vision of a greater Hopkins than I had ever seen before. It is not merely
that President Wilson chose this University as the place among all others
which would best fit him for his great work,—it is the fact that he is a Hopkins man, not in mere outward semblace, but in the spirit. Yet this must not
be taken to mean that he is not also, and in a very deep sense, a Princeton man.
President Wilson knows and loves almost above everything else the Princeton
which has been handed down to him—a heritage which no wealth could have
bought, which no scholarship could have won, except after the life-long
devotion of many men strong in wisdom and in the knowledge of the Lord.
We may be sure that not a stone of this glorious building is to be cast down.
Yet, in his inauguration address, President Wilson distinctly says that he is
going to build something new upon this strong foundation. "We mean," he
says,"
to build a notable graduate college." And when we
hear him proceed to outline this plan, we see that it bears a striking resemblance to something that we have seen before, and have learned to admire with
all due humility. Not that it is a copy of anything else under the sun. President Wilson has very different materials to work with from those of any other
man, and he has a different, an original mind to mould them. But may we
not claim that the source of this new impulse which is to become operative in
one of the most conservative institutions in the country, is to be found in that
great idea which was first put into operation in Baltimore? To claim anything
less, would be to affirm that President Wilson, so closely connected with Johns
Hopkins, has been less affected by it than many thousands of comparative
strangers. Of course, this is to be taken for what it is worth, as the feeling of
one who knows very little of that for which this great University has stood,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

but it may still be an encouragement for study and for life of more value than
the exhortations of the greatest orator that ever lived. As we see the influence
of the Johns Hopkins spreading out into every field of activity—indeed, building upon the firm and tried foundation of a great college with far greater success than upon the more plastic but less secure ground of intellectual chaos to
be found in some less conservative institutions—even the humblest of us must
feel some little desire not to be entirely unworthy of that great University
which we have the right not only to admire but also to love.

$30,000 IN GIFTS TO THE UNIVERSITY.

e•

HE Board of Trustees of the University Monday afternoon accepted two
donations to the Hopkins. The gifts embrace $30,000 and came as a
surprise to the Board.
The offer of Dr Christian A. Herter, of New York, a graduate of the Hopkins, and his wife, to give $25,000 for the foundation of a memorial lectureship
in the medical department was received and accepted. The lectureship "is designed to promote a more intimate knowledge of the researches of foreign investigators in the realm of medical science." This end is to be secured by inviting each year some eminent worker in physiology or pathology to deliver one
or more lectures at the Johns Hopkins University upon a subject with which
he has been identified. The lecturer will receive as an honorarium the annual
income of the endowment.
.
The committee to select the lecturer will consist of Dr. Welch, Dr. Osler
and Dr. Abel, subsequent vacancies in this committee being filled by choice of
the remaining members in stich a way that pathology, physiological chemistry
and clinical medicine shall continue to be represented. There is no bar to opening the proposed lectureship to leaders in medical research in this country, if
this should ultimately appear desirable.
Mr. R. Brent Keyser sent a letter in which he referred to the matter of surveying and looking after the Homewood property, recently donated to the University, and offered to give $5000 to obtain the necessary expert assistance.
The gift was accepted and Mr. Keyser was voted the hearty thanks of the
Board.

0MORROW afternoon, at Westminster, Md., the football team plays its
first game of the season—if we except the eight-minute contest with Loyola
last Saturday. Western Maryland has put up a wonderfully strong game
this season, defeating our old rival, the University of Maryland, sixteen to
nothing. Our light players, with but three weeks of practice behind them, will
have their work cut out and ready for them when they line up at Westminster.
And in recognition of the sporting spirit in which they accept such an unequal
contest, they deserve the immediate and practical support of the entire undergraduate student body. Three years ago a green Hopkins team went up to
Westminster and defeated Western Maryland in a hard fought battle. In
speaking of the game afterwards several of the Hopkins men were heard
to say that it made all the difference in the world to them to hear the J. H. U.
songs and yells which were given with such spirit by the 60 rooters who accompanied the team. Much more will this be the case tomorrow, when our practically untried eleven meets a powerful team. Every man in the four undergraduate classes who can possibly take the time off should add his name to the list
on the bulletin-board of those who are to accompany the team. The train leaves
Union Station at 10.17 a. m., and it is expected that there will be a special car
for the team and rooters. Every man who turns up tomorrow with a flag and
a megaphone and, above all, a voice in good working order, is helping our team
to get the dash and spirit that they will need to win. All aboard!

HERE is one method of assisting the Musical Clubs in their work,—a
method, too, which would produce practical and immediate results,—
which is little practiced at the University. This is, the suggestion to
the leaders of the various clubs of selections suitable for performance. "It is
Very
the leader's business to hunt up good pieces himself," someone says.
true; but it is also the leader's business to do a hundred other things with
which he cannot be helped by outsiders, and it will materially aid him in getting through his work to have ready at hand a large list of selections from
which to choose in making up a program. Of course, each leader attempts to
keep up with the music of the day, and is constantly on the watch for "something that will go," But it is impossible for any one man to keep track of the
mass of new songs, marches and waltzes that are produced every season. He
can attend all the comic operas,—and to some this may seem a not unpleasant
task,—be can keep his ears on the alert for a promising ditty whistled on the
street, and he can even, if he is a nervy man, write music himself. But he cannot fail to miss every season a certain number of new and old selections which
he would have been glad to consider, and possibly to adopt. The moral of all
this is, that every tuneful soul in the college has a chance to help the clubs by
sending in the names of pieces that he thinks will suit.
For the Glee Club, "close harmony" and melodies of a kind to bring out
the contrasts in the different voices are desired; for the Banjo Club, snappy
marches and dances which set the foot involuntarily marking time; for the
Mandolin Club, bright airs and dreamy waltzes. Some who read this may take
the hint, and put the leaders on the track of some good music.

N another page appear some notes on Dr. Woodrow Wilson's inauguration
as President of Princeton University. President Wilson has been connected with many institutions of learning in this country—Princeton,
Wake Forest, Tulane, Vale, Bryn Mawr, Wesleyan, New York Law School.
From several of these he has received degrees. But we are proud to note, from
his own words and declared policy, that his work at the Johns Hopkins, leading
to his Ph.D. in 1886, has ever been an especial source of inspiration and benefit
to him. He is in the first rank of our distinguished graduates, and our pride in
him is mingled with congratulations on the early recognition of his worth.

ously handicapped at being ''cut short" on this time

The first smoker of the Hullabaloo Club was marked by great enthusiasm.
It had been feared by some that the hotly contested class election, which was
scheduled to open that evening, would mar the enjoyment of those present, but
judging by the spirited way in which the numerous songs were sung, and the
appreciation of the refreshments provided, these fears were unfounded. There
was at first some difficulty in getting the piano past the narrow banisters; but
this was overcome by the combined ingenuity and strength of a few leading
spirits, and music held its pleasant sway. Altogether, it was felt that the
smoker was to be the forerunner of many more such enjoyable occasions.

FOOTBALL.
APTAIN BLANCK and the players who stick out the present football
season deserve all kinds of laurels, for they have certainly been "up
against it."
The game with Loyola College at Clifton Park last Saturday was the latest
discouraging incident. A number of new and promising men had been gotten
out for several days before the game, and prospects were much brighter. One
or two slight injuries on the last practice day made it necessary to keep several
of the best men out, but notwithstanding this, it looked as if we were scheduled
for victory over a team like Loyola. The results show that other troubles were
on hand. The teams lined up before a crowd which could not be held within
bounds, and any long run around the end had to be zig-zagged through spectators scattered all over the field. Loyola kicked off, and Hopkins brought the
ball back to the 45 yard line. Hitting the tackles proved effective and the ball
moved along until fumble No. 1 gave Loyola the ball. The collegians fussed
around the ends for several downs and then lost the ball. It was Hopkins
second chance to "get busy" and they did it in great style,—so great, in fact,
that when fumble No. 2 occurred, a Loyola man took the ball on the jump and
dodged in and out among the crowd until he- reached the goal line. In this
point the only park policeman became the most important factor in the game.
The ball had been in play just eight minutes, but it was 4 o'clock, and a permit giving the grounds to the Indians and the Never Sweats from four to six
came to view. And that was the finish. Hopkins left the field disgusted.
Such happenings are unusually discouraging under the present circumstances, but we are bound to stick it out, and there will be a turn in the tide
before the season ends.

SHARSHALL GRASTY, '02, WEARS A HALO.
HE NEWS-LETTER prints below a very interesting clipping from the

C

Staunton News. THE NEWS-LETTER first thought of suppressing the
name of the subject of these encomiums and permitting its readers to
guess who the phenomenal scholar really was, the correct guesser to receive a
prize; but on reconsidering the matter it was felt that no correct guess could be
made, and the prize was therefore divided among the editors of THE NEWS
LETTER. It will be remembered that Mr. Grasty was half of the members of
"The Society for the Suppression of Vice." The following article is worthy of
perusal, as it teaches what great enchantment distance often lends.
"For any student to take the B. A. of Johns Hopkins in four years, while
pursuing a difficult scientific course, is a creditable achievement; but when it is
remembered that Sharshall Grasty entered Johns Hopkins late in the season of
1898.99, not fresh from his books like his classmates, but after two years of hard
work, the achievement may be considered admirable and extraordinary. There
are few finer young men physically, intellectually and morally than Sharshall
Grasty."
This last sentence is good enough to put on his tombstone.

WALTER'S WISDOM.
ALTER ran his hands reflectively through my hair. "Shampoo or hair
cut, sail?"
I'Shave," I answered sententiously. Walter proceeded to arrange
the instruments of torture. Like all barbers, he also proceeded to talk.
"Jes look at that face now, sah; you've been shaving yourself, sah. Ef Ah
had ybu all the time, sah, why you could take that face with you anywhere."
Walter is brutally frank. I protested that I had to take it with me anyway,
but the point was lost on him.
"You are too handsome a man, sah. not to have a clean, smooth face, sah.
You are, sah. Ef Ah had you all the time, sah, do you know what Ah would

TO

do?"
As he had filled my mouth with soap, reply was out of the question.
Walter continued his soliloquy as he stropped his razor.
"You ought to buy one of my tickets, sail, then you would always look
well. Why, there was a gem'mun in here yestiddy, sah, who said you was a
handsome man. Now ef Ah had you all the time Ah'd fix you so's you'd
always look well."
As a freshman that speech flattered my vanity, but I long ago found out
that he uses the same subtle flattery with everyone.
Just as Walter made one of his long sweeps across my classic jaw three
freshmen began to sing about its being always fair weather. Walter looked to
see who was disturbing the peace, and at the same time sliced me with neatness
and despatch. I remonstrated.

THE SOCIAL SETTLEMENT YOUTH.

NCE upon a time there was a youth who went to Levering Hall regularly.
There he was inoculated with a mad desire to lift his brother and to
fight the demon rum in his own den. One night as he was on his way to
a ping-pong party at the Social Settlement, he saw a burly man counting a roll
in front of a liquor shop.
"Stop!" he said to the man with the long green, "don't you know that is
not the place to spend your money?"

O

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The man only glared; then he snorted.
"Do not help to feed the demon rum."
He reached gently for the large individual with the comfortable wad to pull
him away from that haunt of vice and sin. The man thought that he was
making a pass at him; he ducked and countered with left to jaw. The youth
was "some punkins" in the gym, where you fight one minute and rest four, but
in this mix-up the spectators did not even offer Odds.
A few bystanders carried him to the nearest drug-store.
"Who was he?" he asked feebly when he came to.
"Dat!" admiringly exclaimed one of the brats whom the college youth had
come down to elevate, "dat bloke owns de bar. See?"
MORAL,: This fable teaches freshmen never to butt in before they are
introduced.

SILVER JUBILEE MEMORIAL VOLUME.

t

HE Johns Hopkins University Press has issued a beautiful bound volume
containing a complete account of the proceedings held last February on
the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the University.
The volume, which consists of almost 200 pages, contains the addresses of
President Remsen, President Emeritus Gilman, Governor Smith, as well as the
speeches of congratulation delivered by the different University presidents. A
full list of the delegates, representing nearly 100 universities and colleges, is
also given.
The address of Professor Woodrow Wilson, who has just been installed as
president of Princeton University, on his presenting the memorial volume to
Dr. Gilman, together with a copy of the congratulatory address, and Dr. Gilman's reply, are reprinted in full.
The Alumni banquet and the reunions and receptions held in connection
form chapters by themselves.
The work reflects great credit upon those having its publication in charge,
and will be an interesting souvenir to all who were present at the ceremonies,
as well as to the educational world in general. A copy has been presented to
all subscribers to the Alumni banquet.

A series of ten lectures on "The Weather and Climate of Baltimore and
Vicinity" will be given by Dr. Oliver l4. Fassig, on Thursdays at 11, in the
lecture room of the Geological Department. The lectures will extend through
November, December and January; the first will be given on Nov. 6.
The recently organized Geographical Society of Baltimore announces that
the first of its series of lectures for 1902-1903 will take place in McCoy Hall,
November 18, at 8 o'clock, when Dr. Angelo Heilprin will speak on "Martinique." The remaining five lectures will be given at the rate of one each
month until April.

AMF,S. E. ROUTHE, Jr., was at his home in Petersburg, Va., last week
attending the funeral of his uncle, Mr. David Dunlop.
A picture of the class of 1902 now adorns the second floor corridor of
McCoy Hall.
Prof. Robert W. Wood is conducting a series of interesting glass-blowing
experiments in the physical laboratory.

J

Dr. Daniel C. Gilman delivered the address at the first open meeting of the
Pedagogical Club on Saturday, Nov. 1. His paper was in the nature of an introduction to a course of lectures on "The World's Great Educators," which
he will deliver sometime during the current year.
The opening smoker of the Johns Hopkins Club was held on Saturday,
October 25th. Dr. Henry M. Hurd was the speaker of the occasion.
Dr. J. M. Vincent is delivering a course of lectures on successive Wednesday afternoons to the graduate students in history at the University of Pennsylvania. The general subject of the course, which includes 30 lectures, is
"Methods of Historical Research."
A series of lectures on "Art Interpretation and Criticism" to continue
until next April has been begun by Dr. A. V. Churchill, of the Fine Arts department of Columbia University.
President Remsen and Dr. Gilman both took conspicuous parts at the
inauguration of President Woodrow Wilson, of Princeton, on last Saturday.
Dr. Henry M. Hurd was in Philadelphia last week attending the session
of the Hospital Superintendents of the United States.
The volume containing the physical papers of the late Prof. Henry A.
Rowland, announcement of which was made in these columns last spring, is
almost ready for distribution to its subscribers.
Dr. Christopher Johnston was confined to his home last week on account
of sickness.
In a volume recently published by the Outlook Company, entitled "Seen
by the Spectator," there appears an essay, "Johns Hopkins' Quarter Century."
A beautiful edition of Poe's works in 17 volumes has lately been received
by the University.
